text: the world of elite speed skating here in
South Korea has been rocked by
allegations of physical and sexual abuse
this is a country that has 124 Olympic
gold medals but no the standards the
quality of the coaching is being brought
into question five women have come
forward and raised their voices we've
been speaking to one of them anonymously
I was in my first year at high school 16
years old it was a public space at an
ice rink
my coach hugged me and kissed me you
would call me into a separate room alone
and touch me he texted me I love you and
asked me to go to a movie theater or
have dinner it lasted for two years and
then I left a team what did you think
then what was going through your your
brain I felt dirty but I couldn't say no
to his face because I thought my life as
an athlete would end if I left him or
said no to him the pressure was harsh I
was beaten heavily in elementary school
beaten by badminton rackets or the
plastic cover for skate plates
honestly sexual harassment is a problem
but violence is a bigger problem
however in skating it's a given that
you'd be beaten it would have been
considered strange if we reported it
what do you want to say happen to the
man involved I tried not to blame him
but looking back I realized I quit
skating because of him he is
bad-mouthing me now while continuing his
normal life I want him to suffer as much
as I do
[Music]
it all started last year when medallist
shim suk-hee came forward she said she
had been beaten by her coach now Miss
shim has come forward to say she was
sexually abused and she's not the only
one
stars from the world of judo from the
worlds of tennis and football have all
come forward to say they too we're
physically or sexually abused
now Seoul and South Korea might look
glitzy and dynamic but it remains a
patriarchal society it is difficult for
women to question especially men in
power but things are beginning to change
the new - movement is taking hold and
that is because a brave few women have
decided to come forward with their
stories it happened over and over again
in Korea people spoke out it got swept
under the rug and perpetrators acted
again maybe now is the time for a real
change
maybe we can ensure there won't be any
more victims there might be other women
watching hoops suffered like you have
what message would you give them I would
like to tell them that we shouldn't
think that it is our fault we should
seek help let others know and report on
it don't suffer alone
[Music]
